CatDescriptText: Mrs. Aramintha Godfrey, restaurant employee, Uptown and Mr. Hafiz Dawud, airman, Braddock, were part of the Pittsburghers Speak Up column, published in Pittsburgh Courier Newspaper, September 16, 1961, pg. 7 with question: "Do you think that political party policy makers respect the Negro vote and act accordingly, or do they take it for granted?  Why?" Mrs. Godfrey's answer reads: "I think they respect the Negro vote, because they figure that every vote is important in securing office."  Mr. Dawud's answer reads: "Because the Negro does not do anything together and there is no union, the policy makers have no respect for the Negro vote."
TitMainTitle: Two frames: Portrait of Aramintha Godfrey wearing eyeglasses and light colored blouse with floral lace on sleeve hem, carrying paper bag, standing in front of tree, car, and buildings; Portrait of Hafiz Dawud wearing light colored button down short sleeve shirt, standing in front of tree and building
